* [[Moral realism]] is the class of theories which hold that there are true moral statements that report objective moral facts. For example, while they might concede that forces of social [[conformity (psychology)|conformity]] significantly shape individuals' "moral" decisions, they deny that those cultural [[norm (sociology)|norms]] and [[convention (norm)|customs]] define morally right behavior. This may be the philosophical view propounded by [[ethical naturalism|ethical naturalists]], however not all moral realists accept that position (e.g. [[ethical non-naturalism|ethical non-naturalists]]).<ref>[[Georges Chapouthier|Chapouthier, Georges]], To what extent is moral judgment natural ?, European Review (GB), 2004, Nr12(2), pp179-183</ref>
 
* Moral [[anti-realism]], on the other hand, holds that moral statements either fail or do not even attempt to report objective moral facts. Instead, they hold that moral claims are derived either from an unsupported belief that there are objective moral facts ([[error theory]], a form of [[moral nihilism]]); the speakers' sentiments ([[emotivism]], a form of [[moral relativism]]); or any one of the [[norm (sociology)|norms]] prevalent in society ([[ethical subjectivism]], another form of moral relativism).

=== Rational Morality as Harm/Care Morality ===
  +   +
What is the standard for morality is considered to be the continued existence of survival. Survival works as middle junction, wherein well-being and death are possible. These two states are only possible in thought, in morality, as so long a life-form survives, and has consciousness of its biological relationship to the external world. Those things which are thought to cause well being are consequences that maintain the survival of the being(s). That which causes harm moves the existence of the being into a closeness to death.
  +   +
This is a realist and biological take on morality. It does not base morality on good or bad, so much as it bases morality on actual biological reactions and life's relation to other life. Each life form has different relations to its own species and other species, and every culture and person may have different methods of harming and caring for its members. In this theory harming is not so much wrong as it not caring, and caring is not so much right as it not harming.
  +   +
Harm/Care is a ratio, and also may be thought of with an emotional registration of negative/positive. The ratio between these forces of the mind are known for causing cognitive dissonance or internal or external conflicts (as in other's wants vs. self wants). The consequence that causes the most amount of care possible is the most beneficial, and that which causes the most harm is detrimental. One can weigh possible outcomes, in a ratio, and how they translate back into the dichotomy of well-being vs. death. This is also called risk/benefit analysis.

Flight-Fight system – The brain engages in a reaction of avoidance or defense/offense in response to threat. A ratio between strength and fear will determine if the threat has a response of d/o or aversion. Fear is a negative feeling, which is usually trigger by stimulus which is thought of as "threat." This a flight response (along with sadness, disgust, hate) that may be overpowered by anger in a fight response. Environmental conditions, and external influence can play a role in the determination of any response.
